### Objective  
This assignment invites you to connect **the theory of modern banking and digital transformation** with **real-world FinTech business models**.  
You will analyze the economics of a selected FinTech company and report on the related value propositions, challenges and vulnerabilities.

---

### Instructions
1. **Pick one FinTech company** from the list below.  
2. **Study the economics of its business model** in light of the concepts and models discussed in class.  
3. Be prepared to **discuss your analysis in the written exam**, where some questions will directly refer to your chosen company.

---

::: {.callout-tip title="Structure your analysis around the following"}
- **Friction:**  
  Identify the information governance setup and the information friction the Fintech addresses (e.g., information asymmetry, incompleteness, confidentiality)

- **Value Proposition:**  
  Understand how does the company create value and relate it to the above friction. Identify its technological and economic innovation.

- **Revenue Model:**  
  Map out the main way the company makes money. In particular, unpack the allocation of fees and the underlying welfare implications.

- **Theoretical Link:**  
  Relate the company to a model from the course which best helps understand the business model or its role in and challenge for the financial ecosystem.  

- **Challenges:**  Using the appropriate model and the details of the company, list out the main issues faced by the companies. Be ready to deeply unpack each item.
  - **Policy / Regulation:** e.g., compliance, data governance, systemic risk, competition.  
  - **Industry:** e.g., scalability, competition with incumbents, market sustainability.  

- **Vulnerabilities & Threats:**  
  Strictly referring to the class material and the model chosen, assess the main risks or vulnerabilities faced by the company?  
:::

- **Format:** Study can be done in group; reporting is done independently; synthesis expected within the written exam.  
- **Evaluation:** Clarity of reasoning, depth of economic analysis, and ability to connect theory with real-world fintech cases.
